mads:mads.mads:note: Brill's New Pauly: "Perhaps identical with the tragedian Nothippus (5th cent. BC; cf. TrGF 26; DID A3,14 and TrGF 8) [1. 481, 18ff.]; the name G. was possibly used jestingly for Nothippus [2. 399]. In Athenaeus (8,344c f. and 14,638d ff.) they are used for two different persons: in 14,638d ff., due to his new ‘soft’ style, G. is mocked on one hand as a ‘paigniagraphos of the merry muse’ by contemporary comedians (e.g., Cratinus), on the other hand ─ if the transition in 14,638e is to be understood in this meaning [1. 1480,35ff] ─ he is mocked for his lasciviousness as a tragedian, a competitor of Sophocles and son of Cleomachus." Pressler, Frank (Heidelberg). "Gnesippus." Brill's New Pauly. Antiquity volumes edited by: Hubert Cancik and ; Helmuth Schneider . Brill, 2011. Brill Online. Tufts University Library. 07 March 2011‏
